name: Worse Is Better
summary: A software design philosophy arguing that simpler, 'worse' solutions often succeed over more complete but complex alternatives.
explanation: Worse Is Better is a software design philosophy articulated by Richard P. Gabriel in 1989, comparing the 'New Jersey' style (simplicity-first) with the 'MIT' approach (correctness-first). The philosophy argues that simpler solutions with fewer features often win over more comprehensive alternatives because: (1) Simplicity enables adoption - easier to understand, implement, and port, (2) 'Good enough' ships faster - perfect is the enemy of done, (3) Viral growth - simple tools spread more easily, (4) Incremental improvement - starting simple allows organic evolution. The name is provocativeâ€”the 'worse' solution isn't actually worse overall, just worse on paper. Unix succeeded over more sophisticated alternatives partly through this approach. The principle applies to products, APIs, and features: sometimes shipping 80% is better than perfecting 100%.
